summary: a total of 177 international travelers returned to Ontario were considered persons under investigation for MERS-CoV. a total of 177 international travelers were considered persons under investigation for MERS-CoV. a pneumoniae and Chlamydophila pneumophila testing was conducted by using ProPneumo-1 multiplex assay (Gen-Probe Inc., San Diego, CA, USA) PCR was conducted for Legionella species by using a protocol developed by CDC (10); BinaxNOW Legionella Urinary Antigen Test (Binax Inc., Portland, ME, USA) was also conducted to test for L. pneumophila serogroup 1. influenza was the most common virus identified. 27 (15.3%) persons tested positive for influenza A, 14 (7.9%) for A(H3N2) and 13 (7.3%) for A(H1N1)pdm09. 14 (7.9%) tested positive for influenza B. Rhinovirus was also common, detected in 35 (19.8%) persons. no respiratory pathogen was found for 88 (49.7%) among 177 returned travelers. 87 (49.2%) of 177 PUIs during the study period. most influenza B cases were detected shortly after the 2014 Ontario peak. the number of PUIs with influenza is of particular concern. influenza vaccination should be a priority for all persons and should be recommended by health care practitioners who advise travelers.
